title: How Do You Find the Period of a Function?

steps.title: Find the coefficient B in your sine or cosine function.
steps.content: Find the coefficient B in your sine or cosine function. Your function should follow this function formula: f ( x ) = A sin ⁡ ( B x + C ) + D {\displaystyle f(x)=A\sin(Bx+C)+D} or f ( x ) = A cos ⁡ ( B x + C ) + D {\displaystyle f(x)=A\cos(Bx+C)+D} . Identify the value of B in your formula. [1] X Research source None of the other coefficients will affect the period of the sine wave, so you can disregard them for now.

steps.title: Plug B into the formula Period = 2 π / | B | {\displaystyle {\text{Period}}=2\pi /|B|} .
steps.content: Plug B into the formula Period = 2 π / | B | {\displaystyle {\text{Period}}=2\pi /|B|} . This formula is used for both sine and cosine functions, so you can follow the same steps for either. Divide 2 π {\displaystyle 2\pi } by the absolute value of your coefficient B. The absolute value of B is the non-negative value of B. For example, the absolute value is 3 if B equals 3 or -3. [2] X Research source Suppose your sine function is f ( x ) = sin ⁡ ( 2 x ) {\displaystyle f(x)=\sin \left(2x\right)} . In this case, B = 2 {\displaystyle B=2} . Plug 2 into the formula to get Period = 2 π / | 2 | = 2 π / 2 = π {\displaystyle {\text{Period}}=2\pi /|2|=2\pi /2=\pi } . In this case, the period of the sine function is π {\displaystyle \pi } . The same steps are used to find the period of a secant function y = A sec ⁡ ( B x ) {\displaystyle y=A\sec(Bx)} and a cosecant function y = A csc ⁡ ( B x ) {\displaystyle y=A\csc(Bx)} .

steps.title: If your sine or cosine function is sin ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle \sin(x)} or cos ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle \cos(x)} , the period is always 2 π {\displaystyle 2\pi } .
steps.content: If your sine or cosine function is sin ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle \sin(x)} or cos ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle \cos(x)} , the period is always 2 π {\displaystyle 2\pi } . 2 π {\displaystyle 2\pi } is the period for a standard sine or cosine curve. If no other coefficients or variables are introduced to change the period, the period of sin ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle \sin(x)} or cos ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle \cos(x)} will always be 2 π {\displaystyle 2\pi } . [3] X Research source

steps.title: Find coefficient B in tangent function y = A tan ⁡ ( B x ) {\displaystyle y=A\tan(Bx)} .
steps.content: Find coefficient B in tangent function y = A tan ⁡ ( B x ) {\displaystyle y=A\tan(Bx)} . If your tangent function is y = tan ⁡ ( 2 x ) {\displaystyle y=\tan(2x)} , then B = 2. {\displaystyle B=2.} Ignore any other whole numbers in the tangent function; i.e. if the function is y = 8 tan ⁡ ( 3 x ) {\displaystyle y=8\tan(3x)} , you only need to pay attention to 3, which represents coefficient B . [4] X Research source

steps.title: Substitute the value of B into the formula P = π / | B | {\displaystyle P=\pi /|B|} .
steps.content: Substitute the value of B into the formula P = π / | B | {\displaystyle P=\pi /|B|} . Divide π {\displaystyle \pi } by the absolute value of B to find the period of the tangent function. For example, suppose your tangent function is y = tan ⁡ ( 2 x ) {\displaystyle y=\tan(2x)} . [5] X Research source Plug B (2) into the formula to obtain P = π / | 2 | {\displaystyle P=\pi /|2|} . The absolute value of 2 is 2, which leads us to P = π / 2 {\displaystyle P=\pi /2} . Solve the equation to get P = π / 2 {\displaystyle P=\pi /2} . The period of this tangent function is π / 2 {\displaystyle \pi /2} . The same steps are used to find the period of a cotangent function y = A cot ⁡ ( B x ) {\displaystyle y=A\cot(Bx)} .

steps.title: If the tangent function is tan ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle \tan(x)} , the period is always π {\displaystyle \pi } .
steps.content: If the tangent function is tan ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle \tan(x)} , the period is always π {\displaystyle \pi } . A standard tangent function will always have a period of π {\displaystyle \pi } . Therefore, you don’t have to calculate the period for function tan ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle \tan(x)} . [6] X Research source

steps.title: Example Problem 1:
steps.content: Example Problem 1: Find the period of the periodic function sin ⁡ ( 4 x + 5 ) {\displaystyle \sin(4x+5)} . [7] X Research source Solution: B = 4. {\displaystyle B=4.} Period = 2 π / | 4 | {\displaystyle {\text{Period}}=2\pi /|4|} → 2 π / 4 {\displaystyle 2\pi /4} → π / 2 {\displaystyle \pi /2} . The period of sin ⁡ ( 4 x + 5 ) {\displaystyle \sin(4x+5)} is π / 2 {\displaystyle \pi /2} .

steps.title: Example Problem 2:
steps.content: Example Problem 2: Find the period of the periodic function sin ⁡ ( − 8 x ) {\displaystyle \sin(-8x)} . Solution: B = − 8. {\displaystyle B=-8.} Period = 2 π / | − 8 | {\displaystyle {\text{Period}}=2\pi /|-8|} → 2 π / 8 {\displaystyle 2\pi /8} → π / 4 {\displaystyle \pi /4} . The period of sin ⁡ ( − 8 x ) {\displaystyle \sin(-8x)} is π / 4 {\displaystyle \pi /4} .

steps.title: Example Problem 3:
steps.content: Example Problem 3: Find the period of the periodic function tan ⁡ ( 3 x ) {\displaystyle \tan \left(3x\right)} . Solution: B = 3. {\displaystyle B=3.} Period = π / | 3 | {\displaystyle {\text{Period}}=\pi /|3|} → π / 3 {\displaystyle \pi /3} . The period of tan ⁡ ( 3 x ) {\displaystyle \tan \left(3x\right)} is π / 3 {\displaystyle \pi /3} .

steps.title: Example Problem 4:
steps.content: Example Problem 4: Find the period of the periodic function sec ⁡ ( 2 x + 1 ) {\displaystyle \sec \left(2x+1\right)} . Solution: B = 2. {\displaystyle B=2.} Period = 2 π / | 2 | {\displaystyle {\text{Period}}=2\pi /|2|} → 2 π / 2 {\displaystyle 2\pi /2} → π {\displaystyle \pi } . The period of sec ⁡ ( 2 x ) + 1 {\displaystyle \sec \left(2x\right)+1} is π {\displaystyle \pi } .

steps.title: Example Problem 5:
steps.content: Example Problem 5: Find the period of the periodic function 5 cos ⁡ ( 12 x ) {\displaystyle 5\cos \left(12x\right)} . Solution: B = 12. {\displaystyle B=12.} Period = 2 π / | 12 | {\displaystyle {\text{Period}}=2\pi /|12|} → 2 π / 12 {\displaystyle 2\pi /12} → π / 6 {\displaystyle \pi /6} . The period of 5 cos ⁡ ( 12 x ) {\displaystyle 5\cos \left(12x\right)} is π / 6 {\displaystyle \pi /6} .

steps.title: Example Problem 6:
steps.content: Example Problem 6: Find the period of the periodic function cot ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle \cot(x)} . Solution: The period of cot ⁡ ( x ) {\displaystyle \cot(x)} is π {\displaystyle \pi } because it is a standard cotangent function.

steps.title: A periodic function is a function that repeats itself at regular intervals.
steps.content: A periodic function is a function that repeats itself at regular intervals. The period of a function is the distance between each repetition. Periodic functions are represented by the formula f ( x + p ) = f ( x ) {\displaystyle f(x+p)=f(x)} , where p {\displaystyle p} is the period of the function and f {\displaystyle f} is the periodic function. [8] X Research source A periodic function is also defined by having a positive real number (i.e., a number greater than zero) to represent p {\displaystyle p} . Therefore, f ( x + p ) = f ( x ) {\displaystyle f(x+p)=f(x)} is true for x {\displaystyle x} being all real numbers. The fundamental period of a function is the lowest possible value of the positive real number p {\displaystyle p} , or the period in which a function repeats itself. The sine wave is a classic example of a periodic function. The sine wave graph looks like the same wave shape repeated over and over again. The distance between the peaks (or valleys) of each subsequent wave on the graph is the period of the function , as it represents the distance between each repetition.

steps.title: Periodic functions are also defined by amplitude, phase/vertical shift, and frequency.
steps.content: Periodic functions are also defined by amplitude, phase/vertical shift, and frequency. The common form for graphing periodic functions is f ( x ) = A sin ⁡ ( B x + C ) + D {\displaystyle f(x)=A\sin(Bx+C)+D} or f ( x ) = A cos ⁡ ( B x + C ) + D {\displaystyle f(x)=A\cos(Bx+C)+D} , where A = amplitude , B = frequency, –C/B = phase shift , and D = vertical shift . While the period of a function defines the distance between each repetition of the curve, these other coefficients define other dimensions of the graph. [9] X Research source The amplitude of a periodic function is the height or highest point of each peak in a curve pattern. Amplitude can be found by graphing the function, identifying the minimum and maximum values of the function, then halving that difference. That final number is the amplitude. [10] X Research source The frequency of a periodic function is the number of repeated wave patterns within a certain interval. For sine and cosine functions, this interval is often from 0 - 2pi. For tangent functions, it’s typically from 0 - pi. A phase shift is when a curve shifts horizontally on a graph to the left or right of its normal position. The phrase shift does not affect the other variables in a periodic function, i.e. the frequency, period, or amplitude. A vertical shift is when a curve shifts vertically on the graph to be higher or lower than its usual position. If D is negative, the function will shift vertically DOWN the y -axis—if positive, the function will shift upward.
